content.description:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Half-Reaction
 <math alttext="E naught, in volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>V</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="O 2 plus, 4 H with a positive 1 charge, plus 4 electrons, react to produce 2 H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="positive 0.815" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.815</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></math>

<math alttext="N A D with a positive 1 charge, plus H with a positive 1 charge, plus 2 electrons, react to produce N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.320" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.320</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mrow></math>

In human cells a compound known as <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is involved in a reaction that generates an electrical potential. The reaction is based on the two half-reactions shown in the table above. The balanced equation for the overall reaction is shown below.

<math alttext="O 2 plus, 2 H with a positive 1 charge, plus 2 N A D H, react to produce 2 H 2 O plus, 2 N A D with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mtext>NADH</mtext> <mo>→</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"> </mspace> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>NAD</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
content.question: A. How many moles of electrons are transferred for each mole of <math alttext="O 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> that reacts? Justify your answer in terms of the balanced equation and the change in oxidation number of oxygen.

frqParts.text: A. How many moles of electrons are transferred for each mole of <math alttext="O 2" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> that reacts? Justify your answer in terms of the balanced equation and the change in oxidation number of oxygen.
B. Calculate the electrochemical potential of the overall reaction.
C. Calculate the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the overall reaction.

D. When the concentration of <math alttext="N A D H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NADH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases while the concentration of <math alttext="N A D with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>NAD</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases, will the electrochemical potential increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
